properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry mix of precipitation continues this morning. Snow and ice pellets will continue through this morning. Additionally, freezing rain is possible. Precipitation should completely change to snow flurries this afternoon. Given the expected messy mix of wintry precipitation, travel could be impacted across the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T20:59:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T10:22:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3443619387.2021
Area: Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Marathon - Schreiber, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A complex storm is set to arrive today. A Pacific front will reach the North Coast this afternoon and become nearly stationary on a line from Prince Rupert to Sandspit tonight. Heavy precipitation and strong winds will accompany this storm. Current model guidance suggests that Haida Gwaii and Prince Rupert areas could receive significant snowfall on Friday, whereas to the south of the front, Terrace and Kitimat area are expected to see heavy rainfall. Stewart will also see a prolonged period of snowfall tonight through Saturday. Snowfall and rainfall amounts for this event are still up in the air at the moment due to the uncertain position of the front. Weather alerts may be issued at a later time as forecast confidence increases. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-12T04:42:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T12:43:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0766349799.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continues this morning. What: Freezing rain. Ice accretion of 5 to 10 mm is expected in the hardest hit areas. Where: Primarily a corridor along and north of Highway 101, including Timmins. This includes the following highways: -Highway 11 between Kapuskasing and Matheson -Highway 17 between Marathon and Lake Superior Park When: Continuing through early this morning. Discussion: Freezing rain is occurring approximately along and north of Highway 101. Ice pellets are also being reported, and will continue to mix in at times tonight. Total ice accretion of 5 to 10 mm is expected in the hardest hit areas, with isolated utility outages and poor road conditions likely. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T16:59:50-00:00

properties.Title: Dangerous Person Alert Is Being Issued By Meadow Lake Rcmp
properties.Summary:
Description: A dangerous person alert is being issued by Meadow Lake RCMP. Male suspect is identified as 28-year-old Jordan Nelson. He has brown hair and is 5 feet 9 inches tall. Last seen wearing blue jeans and a black hooded sweater with the word 'Northern' printed on the front. Last known to be carrying a large axe or edged weapon. Suspect vehicle: brown four door Ford Fusion. Sask license plate 887 IGF. Last seen travelling on grid roads north of Meadow Lake.
Expires: 2021-03-11T14:00:00-06:00

Area: Community of Meadow Lake, North of Meadow Lake
properties.Author: SK Royal Canadian Mounted Police

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow will continue early this morning. What: Snow. An additional 3 to 6 cm is possible. Where: Thunder Bay. When: Through mid morning. Discussion: Periods of snow will continue through this morning. Periods of steadier snow are possible before 9 a.m., then the snow should gradually taper off. Though amounts are not expected to be overly impressive, some impact to the morning commute is possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain is expected. What: Rain. Total accumulations of 15 to 25 mm are expected. Where: Parts of northeastern Ontario including Chapleau, Gogama, and Kirkland Lake. When: Continuing tonight into Thursday morning. Discussion: Rain will continue tonight. A break in the rain may occur this evening before an additional round overnight. Rainfall accumulations of 15 to 25 mm are anticipated. The ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall due to being frozen and snow covered. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. What: Heavy snow. Total accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are expected with periods of very poor visibility. Where: On a line approximately from Quetico Provincial Park to Pledger Lake, including Geraldton. This includes the following highways: -Highway 11 between Shabaqua Corners and Atikokan -Highway 11 between Nipigon and Highway 631 -Highway 17 between Kakabeka Falls and English River When: Tonight through Thursday morning. Discussion: Snow is moving into Ontario from Minnesota, and is being observed at Thunder Bay Airport. The snow will continue to spread northeast and fall very heavily at times, resulting in rapid accumulation and poor visibility. Area highway conditions will likely deteriorate tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T19:59:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GOLDEN (March 10, 2021 21:00 - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority issued a Dust Advisory for Golden on March 09, 2021. The advisory remains in effect due to high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-12T03:27:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-11T11:28:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2784860862.2021
Area: East Columbia
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow today. What: Heavy snow. Total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are expected. Where: Fort Albany and Moosonee. When: This morning through midnight. Discussion: Periods of heavy snow are expected today, with rapid snowfall accumulation and associated poor visibility. Ice pellets and some freezing rain are also possible this afternoon near or southeast of Moosonee. Snow will weaken this evening but continue until near midnight with a couple of additional cms possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with visibilities less than 400 metres are expected to develop this morning. An approaching low pressure system will impact the Mackenzie Delta today and into Friday. Falling snow and strong northwesterly winds will combine to drop visibilities to below 400 metres for much of the day today. Conditions will improve late this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-12T03:30:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T11:31:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3421445137.2021
Area: Aklavik Region
